div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
div.p: THE ENGLISH DAILY NEWSPAPER
ESTABLISHED 1830
Editor and Manager R. Snelling
Price: ONE PIASTER TARIFF
THURSDAY, APRIL 4TH, 1907

div.head: LORD CROMER'S REPORT.
div.p: Lord Cromer's report for 1906 is at last before us, ad the rumours of its great interest and importance have proved more than justified. It is a remarkable document, frozi whatever point of view it may be regarded and we are convinced that it will make a profound impression on all its readers, for it diseusses with a remarkable frankness and plainness of speech all those questions which the events of the past year have invested with a more than academic importance Egyptian Nationalism and its aims disguised or avowed, the extraordinary vigour, to use a mild 'term, of the criticisms of the Pan-Islamic Press, above all the great question of the Capitulations are all discussed with admira' le lucidity and strength. We expect that the European colonies in Egypt will be most interested in the last mentioned of these issues. Many of us-perhaps too many--are inclined to regard frontier incidents with indifference, t. ask no questions as to the political future of Egypt, to regard most forms of Egyptian Nationalism with mild amusement or bored acquiescence, and to concern ourselves only with the affairs of our particular colony-and the condition of the share or cotton market. But we have all ali certain interest in the Capitulations, which are, to all intents and purposes, our constitution, and no European will but listen with interest to Lord Cromer's proposals as given in his latest report.

RICH COLLECTION OF DESIGNS ORIENTAL AND OTHERS

Lord Cromer complains-and with justice-that his proposals have been unfairly treated in being described as involving "the abolition of the Capitulations." They should mather be said to constitute a "modification of the Capitulations" by which the British Empire takes the place of fifteen different powers. What then are these proposals? We have not the space to give them in full, but we can give at least a summary which will sbow how they affect the average European resident of Egypt for whose benefit they have been made. 1. Should Lord Cromer's proposals be accepted, instead of legislation by diplomacy in all matters regarding European residents in Egypt we shall liave legislation by a local Council composed entirely of Europeans, and subject to the British and Exyptian Governments. No law now requiring the consent of the puwers can come into force until it has been accepted by a majority of the Council and approved by the above mentioned Government 2. Europeans shall be deprived of no right or privelege which they now enjoy under the Capitulations without any adequa e guar. antee being given against the recurrence of the abuses against which their rights and privileges were intended to guard." 3. The Mixed Courts will to all intents and purposes continue to exist under a local obligation, to administer laws passed by the European Legislative Council and approved by the British and Egyptian Governments. Their internationalism is affirmed and a threefold guarantee is offered that there sball be no break in the continuity of the codes which they administe. These guarantees are : firstly, a proposed declaration of the British and Egyptian Governments, secondly, the international character of the cuncil, and thirdly, doabttul questions to be referred 'to the Hague Tribunal 4. The rights of Europeans accused on criminal charges are secured by a series of guaranteus which will ensure that the future European Criminal Courts will adininister justice in * manner at least as satisfactory" as that of the Consular Courts. 5. Domiciliary visits will not be permitted without the authorization of a magistrate who is the subject of a treaty power and the presence of an officer of the court who is a subject of a treaty power. "In other words when a domiciliary visit is effected in the house of an Englishman, a Frenchman, or a German, resident in Cairo or Alexandria, the process will be similar to that which would have taken place in London, Paris, or Berlin, with the exception that the agents employed in carrying on the search instead of being Englishmen, Frenchmen, or Germans may be of some other nationality." 6. In all cases of arrest a European will have the right to be at once liberated on bail or to be brought before a European magistrate within 24 hours of his arrest. Into the question of the composition of the Council we cannot now go. It is important and interesting, but far more important is ord Cromer's note (p 11) on the duration of the British Occupation of Egypt. Here we have the guarantee that the new system, if adopted, well not be nullified by reason of any sudden reversal of British policy, "the question of the 1 duration of the occupation is left to the discretion of the British Government. It will last as long as that Government considers. it necessary in the interests of all concerned, in the welfare and good government of Egypt"... His Majesty's Government "recognise that the maintenance and development of such reforms as have hitherto been effected in Egypt depend upon the British Occupation. This consideration will apply with equal strength to any changes effected in the regime of the capitulations His Majesty's G verdient therefore wish it to be understood that there is o reason for allowing the prospect of any modifications in that regime to be prejudiced by the existence of the British Occupation of the country. We commend this declaration to the attention of our nationalist critics. It is of great importance to every resident in Egypt, European and native, from the Khedive to the humblest fellah, giving as it does the surest of guarantees that the onward march of Egypt shall not be turned to retreat by the forces of absolutism or reaction.

div.head: H.M.S. Minerva
div.p: H.M.S. Minerva (2nd class cruiser) arrived at alexandria at ten 'o'clock this morning from Malta.

div.head: Execution at Cairo.
div.p: Abdul-Moule Mohamed, who was condemned to death for wilful niurder, was executed yesterday morning in the prison of the Cairo Governorat.

div.head: Return of the Mahmal
div.p: The Holy Carpet is expected to arrive in Cairo on the 12th inst. from Tor The reception ceremony will then be held on the 15th inst., on which date the Government Departments will be closed for the occasion.

div.head: Alleged Theft at Tor
div.p: The Emir El Hag has informed the authorities that valuable jewels belonging to his wife, were stolen recently during disinfection at Tor. An inquiry into the matter is being held by the Mamour of the quarantine office.

div.head: The British Club
div.p: A musical entertainment will be given at the British Club, 15 Boulevard de Ramleh, on Saturday next, commencing at 9 p.m. to members and their lady friends Programmes will be issued in the club on the evening of the concert.

div.head: Irrigation Department
div.p: Sir William Garstin's report respecting the Irrigation Works is expected to be published this month The Adviser to the Ministry of t Public Works will leave for the Upper Nile i provinces shortly, and it is expected that he will also visit the Sudan.

div.head: The Egyptian Institute
div.p: The next meeting of the Egyptian Institute will be held on Monday. Dr. Elliot Smith will b read a report on the unrolling of the mummies + of the Kings Siptah, Seti II., Ramses IV, in Ramses V., and Ramses VI. Yacoub Pasha i Artin will read a paper on the four lamps of enamelled and emblazoned glass belonging to Mr. Pierpont Morgan, and papers will also be read by M. Domenico Limongelli and M.M. Roche and Pellet.

div.head: The Ministry of Education
div.p: The Ministry of Public Instruction has decided to send twelve pupils of the Normal School at Cairo,-six each of the first and second years' classes--to England to complete their studies at an English University. On their return to Egypt with the necessary diplomas, they will be appointed professors in the Egyptian secondary schools The Agricultural and Industrial Department is now preparing the necessary programme for the teaching of horticulture at the Ghizeh Agricultural School.

div.head: Societe Internacionale des Employee
div.p: At the meeting of the Société Internationale des Employés d'Alexandrie, which was held on Tuesday evening, the following committee waş appointed : President, Mr G. Rubbé ; VicePresidents, Messrs. G Soulos and J. Dendrinos; Secretary, Mr. A. Caut , Assistant Secretary, G. Vasnier ; Treasurer, Mr. D. Sabella ; Assistant Treasurer, Mr. A. Maravelli; Archivist, Mr. Ph. Sarkis ; Advisers, Messrs. Acriviadit, Albaghi, Bon Jean, J. Faraggi, H. Gueron, Aron Lovy, Mignot, S. Minarich, Nardi, Ed. Paris, F. Santorelli, D. Steinberg, and R. Vautier.

div.head: The Legislative Council
div.p: The Legislative Council will he held on the 10th. inst, in order to deal with the demands of the General Assembly. The demands in question are five viz : 1. To reform the Mehkemeh Shurieh, 2. The Ghaffir service, 3. The Maglis-elHesbi, 4 The appointment of Omdels and Sheikhs of villages, and their trial, 5. To. refer the regulations and programmes of education to the Legislative Council. The report of the commission appointed by the same Council to study the question of public safety in the desert, will also be dealt with.

div.head: Khedivial Geographical Society
div.p: The Khedivial Geographical Society have decided to confer the diploma of "membre d'honneur" upon his Royal Highness Louis · Amédée de Savoie Duc des Abruzzes in recognition of the services rendered to geography by him in his voyages, and notably to African geography, by his recent exploration of the chain of the Ruwenzori. The official conferment of the diploma will take place in the hall of the Legislative Council (Ministry of Public Works) on Saturday afternoon at four o'clock. Professor Schweinfurth, Honorary President of the Society, and Abbate Pasha will deliver speeches.

div.head: The Cairo Tramways
div.p: The following agreement has been made between the Egyptian Government and the Cairo Tramway Company - The Tramway Company is authorised to carry its lines across the bridge from Boulao to the island of Ghezireh, to cross the island and the bridge over the Bahr el Aama, in order to reach Embabeh. The Company is given a concession for a line on the left bank of the Nile, connecting Embabeh with the Pyramids live near the Kasr en Nil bridge. The Company, on its part, undertakes to hand over to the Government the sum of L.E. 200,000 to partly cover the expenses of making new streets and roads over which the new lines will pass.

div.head: NOTICE
div.p: Nicola Pappa begs to announce to his numerous customers and the public in general, that he is removing his General Grocery Stores and Bar to new premises in 21 (cherif Pacha Street, at the comer of Antoniadis Street. The opening will take place on Saturday next at 6p.m.

div.head:
THE NATIONALIST PROGRAMME
SIR AUCKLAND COLVIN'S VIEWS
MANUFACTURED TO ORDER

div.p: Sir Auckland Colvin, writing in the "Nineteenth Century and After," controverts Mr. Dicey's conclusions in his recent work Sir Auckland Colvin considers that the so called Nationalist programme betrays marks of having been manufactured to order. It has, he says, been clearly faked up for foreign consumption and mechanically repeats the mot d'ordre from some hidden source of inspiration.

div.head: ASSOUAN DAM
div.p: In the House of Commons on Monday week Mr. H. C Lea asked the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs whether his attention had been drawn to the resolution come to by the Egyptian authorities to proceed with the increasing of the height of the Assouan dam by seven metres; whether last year doubts were raised by men of scientific eminence as to whether the strains and stresses at present , borne by the Assouan dam had been properly calculated; whether he had satisfied himself as to these fears by inquiry of the best engineering experts ; and, if not, would he consider the advisability of suggesting to the authorities in Egypt the appointment by them of a small committee of scientific men to go thoroughly into the matter, and so obviate the possibility of an accident happening which might cause disastrous loss of life and property Mr Runciman replied that a despatch had · been received from Lord Cromer explaining the reasons which had led the Egyptian Government to arrive at the decision to raise the dam. In due course it would be presented to Parliament. In the meanwhile, it was not desirable to answer questions upon isolated points in connection with the matter.

div.head: TELEGRAPH IN THE SAHARA
div.p: The "Temps" states that it has been decided by the Algerian Government to extend the line which now terminates at Beni-Abbes to Adrar, in the Oasis of Touat. The length of this new line is 248 miles, and the eost is set down at from £12,000 to £16,000. It is understood that the work, which will require about three months to execute, will be taken in hand next autumn. A new form of metallic telegraph pole will be employed, and when this line has been completed a further extension to In-Salah is contemplated, with the ultimate object of crossing the desert.

div.head: NEW SUDAN COMPANY
div.p: Mr. A. Bonnel de Mezieres, Administrateur délégué, and Mr. George Guba, expert appointed by the Board of Directors of the "Crédit Soudanais" are at present in Khartoum to conclude the final arrangements with Mr. Albert Singer, the Khartuum merchant, for taking over his business and starting the new company which will be posted within the next few days. It appears the shares have been privately and fully subscribed, but in deference to the many demands inade and in consideration: tion of the fact that the company's work lies in the Sudan, an effort is being made to appropriate a limited number of £4 shares for subscription at Khartoum. Mr. Singer, who is one of the founders and a large shareholder will be general manager of the company in the Sudan, and that there will be a continuity of his business and his connection as hitherto, while giving same a more extended sphere in the object of the company, which is to entertain any sound commercial and industrial. business requiring financial assistance and Co-operations The capital of the company is *L.E. 200,600 with power to augment it as the business may require.

div.head: EGYPTIAN TRADING AND FINANCE
div.p: A company with the title Egyptian Trading and Finance Company Ltd. has just been formed in Alexandria by Messrs. Kyriacopoulo Brothers and Company the well-known stockbrokers of Alexandria, with a capital of £100,000 divided into 100,000 shares of £1 each, the subscription list of which will open very shortly. · The Administrative Council of the Company is composed of well-known and highly capable meu of business, whose names will be published later. The object of the company is to undertake any kind of commercial or financial transactions, and continue the business of the well known firm of Messrs Kyriacopoulo Brothers and Company. The company is being floated under most favourable circumstances and should meet with great success from the day of its inauguration.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The Ellerman liner Algerian sailed from Malta yesterday evening for Tripoli and Alexandria.

div.head: MILITARY TAILORS.
div.p: EGYPTIAN ARMY OUTFITS A SPECIALITY.
RIDING BREECHES.
F. Phillips & Co.

(high class work only).
CAIRO & ALEXANDRIA.

div.head:
LORD CROMER'S REPORT
HOME PRESS APPROVAL
div.p: Both Liberal and Conservative newspapers alike praise the conclusions made by Lord Cromer in his report for the year 1906, and for his full, frank statement of the present position of affairs in Egypt.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: The Khedive drove yesterday morning from Koubbeh to Abdeen Palace where he gave audience to Count Bernsdorff, German Consul General in Cairo, and Mr. Iddings, American Diplomatic Agent, who presented to his Highness Mr. Evan, and Mr. Alexander Powell, the new American Consul in Alexandria. This morning his Highness-gave audience at Abdeen to Sheikh Hassouna el Nawawi, Chan. cellor of Al Azhar University. The Khediva will attend midday prayer tomorrow at Al Azhar mosque.

div.head: THE MOORE CASE
div.p: Mr. Moore is bringing an action for damages against the three newspapers belonging to Mustapha Pasha Kamel, El Lewa," "The Egyptian Standard," and "L'Etendard" for their allegations of corruption against him. Mr. Moore is also bring similar actions against "El Minbar,"? "El Ahram," and "Les Pyramides." The commission of enquiry instituted by the Egyptian Government to inquire into the charges brought by some native journals and also by the General Assembly against Mr. More has been completed, and Mr. Moore has been exonerated without the slightest suspicion against him. As, we announced in our issue of Thursday last, his accusers will be brought to trial,

div.head:
UM RUS MINES OF EGYPT.
OPERATIONS TO BE DISCONTINUED
div.p: The ordinary general meeting of the Um Rus Gold Mines of Egypt (Limited) was held last week in London. Mr. John Harvey presided and after referring to the history of the mine, he stated that the mining reports seemed to indicate a position which was growing from bad to worse, and those received of late held out no inducement to the company to continue operations. The opinion of the board and of the managers was that operationsshould cease in order to prevent money from being frittered away in useless operations. Sir Henry Bunbury seconded the motion. After a shareholder had expressed strong dissatisfaction with the state of affairs, the report was adopted. By an informal resolution the shareholders present expressed the opinion that the operations should be discontinued and the assets disposed of with a view to the liquidation of the company.

div.head: M. CHARTRAN IN EGYPT.
div.p: The following details of the visit of the famous French painter, M Chartran, in Egypt appears in the latest «Gaulois :". " Des bords du Nil, nous arrive l'écho des honneurs dont a i té l'objet l'un de nos grands artistes, M. Chartran « Présenté à S. A. le Khédive, au palais d'Abdine, par M Chevandier de Valdrôme, gérant diplomatique de la 1.gation de France, il a été accueilli par le prince avec une grâce souriante et un intérêt tout particulier. " Le Khedive n'ignorait ni le talent ni les belles œuvres de M. Chartran. Il l'a questionne longuement sur son séjour en Egypte et lui a témoigné la plus vive sympathie. " Quelques jours plus tard, un banquet était! offert à M. et , Mme Chartran, préside, par, M. de Valdrôme, au Club kh-divial, qui est le premier cercle du Caire et le plus recherché. Parmi les con ives : Mme Klobukowski, Mme Paul Bert, M. Roux, le vicomte de Felcourt, o consul de France et Mme de Reffye, le représentant et le consul général des Etats-Unis, M et Mme Psycha, Miss Carow, scur de Mme Roosevelt ; le comte de Vauvineux, M. et Mme Arakel bey Nubar. " M Chartran n'était allé en Egypte que pour se reposer, mais qui laisse reposer le talent? La légation de France lui e organisé un atelier lans så merveilleuse residence, construite en tyle arabe par le comte de Saint-Maurice, et 'éminent artiste a tout de suite accepté de aire le portrait de la comtesse de Serionne, ine des plus charmantes femmes de la colonie française, dont le mari, représentant de la Soiété du canal de Suez, oocupe une haute situaion au Caire."

div.head:
THE ROYAL VISIT
K.S.C. GYMKHANA
div.p: The last gymkhana of the season was held under most favourable circumstances, being graced by the presence of our Royal visitors, H.H. the Khedive and Lady Cromer, and being favoured by one of the brightest and warmest days we have seen this year. H.H. the Khedive arrived quite early in the afternoon and was present in the royal box in time to witness the first event. It must have been about half past three that the carriage containing the Duke and Duchess of Connaught and Lady Cromer entered the ground, driving across the turf, preceded by mounted policemen and escorted by two officials on bicycles, and in front of the grand stand and enclosure to the box, where they were greeted by the Khedive, Major General Bullock, Sir Vincent Corbett, Sir William Garstin and others. Princess Victoria arrived shortly afterwards and dur ag the afternoon various ladies had the honour of being invited to the royal enclosure. The events of the afternoon were of à most popular and entertaining nature, and though there were several accidents there were none of a serious nature. The jumping competition was most interesting, Captain Leigh's prowess evoking great enthusiasm, and the pig sticking competition caused general amusement, the pig, represented by an inflated water skin at the end of a long rope, proving a most sporting and highly eccentric target. The polo match on donkeys too proved most entertaining, for the humble quadrupeds had no idea of what was expected of them, and anbled about in an aimless fashion, stumbling whenever they could, with a delightful unconcern of the rules of the game. It was a difficult game to follow, even though pace was no object, and the ball was a big one ; but it proved one of the most interesting events of the afternoon, and doubtless afforded the donkeys material for cogitation during the coming months of summer idleness. There was so much to watch and so many people to notice that there was little time to regret the passing of so nany of our late visitors. The stand was full throughout the afternoon, and most of the résidents were to be seen in the enclosure. Mrs and Miss Bullock and Mrs. Findlay were įmong those who finished the afternoon in he royal box, and Lord and Lady Lanesborongh ind Lady Vivian were noticed during the įfternoon the latter with Mrs. Rom who was vearing a most delightful frock of maslin potted with black and with deep black edged orderings of watteau design and colouring. The Misses York were wearing the very prettiest of white mu-lin frocks, and Miss Leverich was also in white with a blue sash. Miss Erskine Shaw who came with Mrs. and Miss Bennett, was much admired in a beautifully fitting semi-Empire frock of biscuit cloth and Mrs. Montague Summer's toilette of vieux rose voile, with passementerie of dull gold about the lace yoke was most becoming Bcth Mrs Nolan and Miss Moore were in muslin, the one having pink ribbons and the other white run through the lace insertions ; and Miss Luck was wearing a sweetly pretty frock of fine black and white striped muslin with a lace corsage showing under the little bolero, The Misses de Villebois were dressed alike in blue silk, and the Misses Çoles were in pink. Among others present were the Countess Hedda Brookdorff, Sir John and Lady Rogers, Sir Vincent Corbet, Mme. de Villebois, Col. and Mrg Campbell, Col and Mrs. Drummond Hay, Col and Mrs Gordon and Miss Mitchell, Col. Persee, Col. Hall, Crookshank Pasha and Mrs. Crookshank, Mr. and Mrs. Comfort, Captain and Mrs. Schreiber, Miss Hurley Mrs Loraine Barrow, Mrs. Leverich, Mrs. York, Mrs and Miss Chakour, Miss Macgillicuddy, Miss Makellar, Miss Baker, Mrs. Bewley, Misc Gomlinson, Mr. and Miss Eddy, Captain and Mrs. Clifford Hall, Mrs. F. W. Saunders, Mr and Mrs. Chatterton Adams, Miss Coke and Miss Farrar, Mr. and Miss Farnell, Major Pirie, Miss Cox and Miss Munro, Mr. Maron, Mr. Randolph Berens, Mr. A. Nungovich, Mrs. and Miss de Codt, Mrs. and Miss Keith, Mr. Wigham, Captain and Mrs. Gillson.

The following are the results of the various events : Subalterng Race. - I. Mr. Jervis Smith, Cold stream Guards ; II. Mr. Paget, Coldstream Guards ; III. Mr Horschitz. I loyd Lindsey. - Major Paterson's Team, Inniskilling Dragoons. Polo Scurry.--I. Mr Jervis Smith, Coldstream Guards ; II Mr. Ogilby, Mr. Spier, dead heat. Jumping Competition.-1. Capt. Leigh. Hurdle Race.-I. Capt Leigh. Pigstick Competition. - Unfinished Polo Match on donkies.--Capt. Eden's Team. On Tuesday evening their Royal Highnesses the Duke and Duchess of Connaught, and Princess Patricia of Connaught were the guests of Major-General Bullock, C.M.G. and Mrs. Bullock at General's House. After dinner a reception was held, at which sev. eral officers of the Army of Occupation were presented to their Royal Highnesses. Last night a banquet was given by Lord and Lady Cromer at the British Agency and among those who were presented to their Royal Highnesses were the Ministers, Advisers, and Under-Secretaries of State Yesterday afternoon the Duck.ess of Connaught and Princess Patricia drove out to Koubbeh and visited the Khedivah.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Mr. Leo Weinthal, F. R. G. S managing director of the "African World," who has been spending two months in Cairo, on business, left for London yesterday by the S.S, Hohenzollern. Dr, Henry van Dyke, the famous essayist, who has just resigned his professorship of literature at Princetown College, has started for a tour in Palestine: A lecture entitled "an expedition from the Niger to the Nile" will be delivered to the Royal Geographical Society on May 13 by Lieut. Boyd Alexander.

div.head:
Zizinia Theatre
M. De Feraudy
div.p: If circumstances compelled our absence on Monday at the first of a welcome series of plays, we are not conceited enough to ima. gine we owe any apology other than to M. de Féraudy and his company. And it is not a mere shuffling excuse to say that if his Isidore Lechat of ļast Monday was as masterly and vehement as when we last saw him. in the part, the performance was beyond criticism, M de Féraudy is perhaps at his best in "Les Affaires sont les Affaires" and it was a sine quâ non that the play is included in his repertory ; at the same time he no doubt fully realised the boldness of producing it here, for the Lechats, like the poor, are always with us and nowhere more so than in Alexandria ; it is quite on the cards that some were present on Monday and we are sorry to have missed an interesting spectacle, viz the real Lechats' scrutiny of M. de Feraudy's treatment of the subject. We do not for a moment say we have mot any Lechats to equal that of M de Féraudy, or rather of Octave Mirbeau ; they have probably not been victims to circumstances in which to shew such strength of character or it may be they want. the strength of character which would render similar tense and bittar circum. stances feasible. But both the real and stage Lechats (and there is little to choose between them) thanks to M. Mirbeau's ingenuity and M. de Féraudy's remarkable conception of the part, are at any rate free from the hyprocrisy of concealing a love and display of wealth, which is a decided merit. There were no special merits about any of the characters (if such mere talking machines can be so called) in "Paraitre," which was given last night. M Donnay has attempted,like so many modern playwrights, to denounce the shortcomings of society and in particular to break a lance with snobbishness, which is practically co-existent with society. His intention is praiseworthy enough from a moralist's point of view but his way of expressing it in this four-act-five-scene pièce de salon is singularly unconvincing. There is so much irrelovant talk, so many unnecessary persons that it is difficult to get at the backbone of the play at all. Perhaps one is not meant to get there, for everything is done to divert one's attention with a series of intrigues and liaisons of an extraordinary description. Furthermore many of the impersonators should be provided with some palpable cause or other for entering and leaving the stage and for indulging in long and often lugubrious conversation.. The brunt of trying to keep the audience interested fell upon Mmes Van Doren (the injured wife ) Bressan (the transgressing wife) MM. Sévérin (the transgressing husband) and Bauer (the injured husband and incidentally i he brother of the injured wife.) M. de Feraudy's part was quite a supernumerary one and he charmed his audience more by his reposeful speech and gesture than by anything very striking in the shape of dialogue.

div.head: Comission Municipale
div.p: Sonnelles des conseillers et des intérêts vitaux de la Ville, qu'ils ont cependant à cour. On débute avec les communications diverses M. le Baron de Menasce eroit devoir rectifier une inexactitude parue dans un journal lui prêtant à la dernière assemblée une attitude qu'il n'a pas prise à l'égard du Directeur Général des Donanes. Il insiste pour que le compte rendu officiel paraisse dans un journal au moins.. M. Salvago demande ensuite une application plus rigoureuse par la police du Règlement sur les Automobiles. Il signale les nombreux dangers que touré debwiiement le public durs its principales rues de la ville et propose comme palliatif certainės mesnres pratiques. Une discussion s'ensuit à laquelle prennent part M.M. Padoa Bey, Rothaker, de Menasce, qui critiquent le Règlement en vigueur. M. Borghrevink répond à ces critiques en disant que ce Règlement n'est pas aussi doux qu'on le prétend puisque il prévoit même l'emprisonnement comme penalité. Il propose néanmoins d'attirer l'attention du Gouvernement sur l'insuffisance de ce Règlement en ce qui concerne la vitesse qui est fixée à 15 kilomètres à l'heure au centre de la ville et qui ne fixe pas de limite hors de la ville La motion suivante est par conséquent votée : La Commission exprime le veu que le Gouvernement prenne d'urgence les mesures voulues contre la vitesse excessive des automobiles qui occasionne des dangers et des inconvénients incessants et renvoie aussi une at de plus approfondie à l'examen du Conten tieux. La Commission donne ensuite commnnication de plusieurs lettres ministérielles entre cutres une émanant du Ministère des Travaux Publics qui explique l'impossibilité d'avaisser la voie ferrée actuelle. M. de Menasce propose une déviation de ette ligne qui constitue une barrière gêlante au centre de la ville et qui privera "au quartier de Moharem bey la vue sur les parcs projetés Sur la demande de M. Rothaker, la Sommission décide de demander aux services omp-tents les côtes et le coût du projet. M. Rieti d-veloppe enfin son interpellation ur les maisons à bon marché. Il fait avec Jeaucoup de clarté l'historique de la question qui traine d puis si longtemps et qui risque de 'éterniser sans un sacrifice de la part de la leterniser sans un sacrifice de la part de la Municipalité. Il propose donc à celle-ci de faire bandon de la quote part qui lui revient dans a vente du terrain destiné par le Gouvernenent aux maisons ouvrières. Un groupe de inanciers est disposé à préter son concours à ette euvre intéressante et accepte d'ores et léjà à se soumettre à toutes les conditions que oudra bien lui imposer la Municipalités Me 'adoa bey fait remarquer que ces financiers hilanthropes parlent d'un taux de 5 et 5 1/2 %. Sur la demande de ce deruier la Commission journe toute décision jusqu'à la prochaine. Lssemblée, afin de permettre au Comité nommé d hoe de fournir dans cet intervalle les plans t devis ainsi que tous les éléments nécessaires our lui permet re de se prononcer en con: aissa..ce de cause, M. E. Stross expose ensuite la question de introduction de l'eau filtrée à Ramleh, qu'il oudrait voir à la portée de tous les habitants. s'élève contre les agissements de la Com agnie des Eaux envers le public et contre le conopole de l'eau qu'il ret ent plus onéreux ue celui du gaz ou de l'électricité dont on est tant préoccupé dernièrement. M. Salvago déclare, en sa qualité d'Adminisateur de la dite Compagnie, que cette dernière st disposée à accueillir favorablement tout rojet que la Municipalité voudra bien lui resenter en modification de ses arrangements ntérieurs. Il reconnait quelques défauts au ystème actuel, mais promet d'y apporter remède. les franches déclarations ont produit la leilleure impression. Mr S. Abani Bey a fait éanmoins une charge à fond contre la Companie en denonçant énergiquement ses procédés rbitraires. Sur la proposition de Me Padoa Bey la Comission délégne M. Chataway pour rechercher, e concert avec les Administrateurs de la dite ompagnie, le meilleur moyen d'arriver à un rrangement permettant une fourniture d'ean Itrée à des conditions plus raisonnables. La séance est levée à 7 h. 30, la continua. on de l'ordre du jour est renvoyée à la prohaine assemblée. BANCO DI ROMA. OCIETA ANONIMA, CAPITALE VERSATO £rt. 40.000.000. SEDE DI ALESSANDRIA, (EGITTO). div.p: Escomptes---Paris 3, Londres 2 ½, Berlin 3

div.head:
THE HAGUE CONFERENCE
THE DISARMAMENT QUESTION
GREAT BRITAIN INSISTS

div.p: Great Britain insists on her proposal to place the question of disarmament on the programme of the Hague Conference, but accompanies it with the suggestion to refer the matter to a committee to be compose 1 of members of the Conference, from which naval and military men should be excluded. (Reuter)
Three failures occurred on the Stock Exchange yesterday, and to-day, including an old-established broker. A considerable amount is involved. (Reuter)

div.head:
PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT AND MR. HARRIMAN
ALLEGATIONS AND DENIALS

div.p: "A sensation has been caused in the United States by a quarrel between President Roogevelt and the railroad magnate, Mr. Harriman. The latter alleges that the President instigated him to contribute to the republican funds collected for the presidential election of 1904. The President describes the allegation as a deliberate and wilful untruth (Reuter)

div.head:
THE RUSSIAN BUDGIT
PRESENTED TO THE DUMA

div.p: The Minister of Finance has presented the budget to the Duma. He stated that he had contrived to make the ordinary expenditure and revenue balance each other, but that the extraordinary expenditure for famine and war settlements, amounting to £29,000,000, would probably nedessitate a loan. :'. (Reuter)

div.head:
RUSSIA AND PERSIA
THE MUDER OF SALZEVAR

div.p: According to a telegram received from Tehran, Russia has demanded punishment of the murderers of Salzevar, a guarantee of the safety of Russian subjects, and indemnity for the victim's family. (Reuter)

div.head:
THE BITLIS EARTHQUAKE
FURTHER CASUALTIES AND HAVOC

div.p: Still stronger shocks of earthquake have occurred at Bitlis resulting in further casualties and havoc (Reuter)
The prefects all report that tranquillity has been restored everywhere. (Reuter)
The masters of twenty-nine cotton looms have declared a lock-out. (Havas)

div.head:
RUSSIA AND PERSIA

THE MUDER OF SALZEVAR

div.head: MID-LENT CARNIVAL.
div.p: The so-called Mid-Lent carnival has beer kept this year by the native Greeks in a rather more marked manner than usual. Certainly the spectacle of a few whimsically, slovenly | dressed men parading the streets in scattered twos and threes, with apparently no definite scheme of amusement and with an entire absence of fun and gaiety, other than the lugubrious noises which they utter by way of song, cannot be inspiring even to themselves and seems very far removed from those cheerful carnival scenes with which one is familiar elsewhere. We may, however see the idea | further developed here, and a "battle of | flowers" and such like events, borrowed from other countries of the Mediterranean, may become a recognized annual fixture.

div.head: POSTAL REDUCTIONS
div.p: On the 1st February last reductions in the rates of postage between Cyprus and the undermentioned countries took place : The Commonwealth of Australia. (including Now South Wales, Queensland, South Australia, Western Australia; Victoria, Tasmania, the Territory of Papua and Norfolk Island) Caicos Islands, Tristan d'Acunha, Afghanistan (for pre-payment as far as the Indian frontier only) Rhodesia and Bechuanaland. The new ratés are :- for each letter not exceeding oz in weight 30 paras"; for every additional foz in weight 30 paras.

div.head: TRAFFIC REGULATIONS
div.p: A Bill 'is to be introduced into the Legislative Council the session to provide for the numbering and licensing of public vehicles, and for regulating the fares payable in respect of them.

div.head: THE KING'S ADVOCATE,
div.p: Mr. Stanley Fisher is appointed to act as King's Advocate till the arrival of Mr. J. Backwill, who is to succeed Mr Rees Davies, in that position.

div.head: BANKS FOR THE VILLAGES
div.p: It is gratifying to learn that the Co-operative Village Banks movement, which was start ed in the Paphos district some two years ago, has spread and that now same 22 little village banks are in existenee, doing apparently a use. ful work in encouraging thrift and in lending out money to the small villagers who are associated with them The Commissioner of the district has taken much personal interest in these banks, which owe not a little to his zeal and private exertions.

div.head: SHEEP-POX PREVALENT
div.p: The return for this district of the number of sheep and goats shows an increase in the former and a decrease among the latter Similar results are anticipated in the other districts. The decrease of goats may be attributed to heavy exports and a good deal of disease. There has also been not a little sheeppox and at present it exists with some severity in certain parts of the island.

div.head: THE NIÇOSLAN RAMPARTS,
div.p: It is unfortunate that the masonry of the fine old ramparts surrounding the town of Nicosia should be falling down in many places. The collapse has beeii in progress for some time past and it is sad that nothing is being done to check the gradual ruin of one of the most interesting and historical features of this ancient city.

div.head: FAMAGUSTA RESERVOIRS
div.p: It is a matter of satisfaction that the reservoirs in the Famagusta district, which were built by the Government scme six years ago, are this year well filled. The question of irrigating the large tract of land served by them during the summer is now no longer in doubt.

div.head: ENGLISH SCHOOL SPORTS
div.p: The annual sports of the English school at Nicosia took place on Saturday, 23rd instant, on the crisket ground. There was a large attendance, including his Excellency the High Commissioner, and Lady King Harman, Sir Robert Biddulph and the Government House party. The sports were good and; as the school numbers some seventy boys, the entries for the different events were numerous.

div.head: The Money Market
div.p: The money market, which was very easy at the beginning of the week, has formed up for the settlement, and whereas money was fairly plentiful at 3 per cent., the charge is now fully i per cent. higher, though there is no difficulty in getting all the accomodation required. It is | thought that the action of the American Secretary to the Treasury, by which some 17,000,000 dollars are released for the benefit of the market in New York, will prevent the necessity of gold shipments for the present Early in the week there were some large quantities of gold obtainable, but America only took £500,000 of it, declining to pay a high rate, and it looks as if the large bill-houses saw little prospect of making profits out of exports in the near future. *** Discount rates have firmed up, and 60 days' bills are quoted 5 per cent.

div.head: The Stock Markets
div.p: Very exaggerated accounts have been circulated as regards the condition of affairs on the Stock Exchange this week. There has no doubt been considerable tension, but in the best circles it was well-known that the account open was comparatively small, and that no very large house was in any way involved. With the exception of four failures of small significance, the account has gone smoothly enough. At the same time, it is known that two houses of somewhat larger proportions have been assisted, and that a certain amount of wreckage has still to find a market. There is no probability, however, of this being pressed for sale, as both these accounts" have been taken over by firms of colossal wealth, who can well afford to keep them for much higher prices. The crisis, such as it is, has come and gone. It has existed largely in imagination, but in the end will no doubt be productive of a considerable increase of confidence. Indeed, things are brighter to-day than they have been for some time past, and prices are certainly at & level to attract bona fide investors.

div.head: Consols
div.p: In the debacle on Saturday Consols were at oně time put down to 848 for money and 84 for the account, but they have since shown a steady recovery, and leave off to-day at 85% for cash.

div.head: Foregin Bonds
div.p: The international section has been dull, but the tone is now much more favourable. Yesterday most of the stocks were very firm. Russian Fives which dropped on Saturday, developed | a sharp recovery, and finished it higher on Monday, while the Fours gained a full point. Yesterday both series registered a.gain of }, the new loan closing at 84 and the Fours at | 76. Japanese were also much stronger, the First Four-and-a-half per cent. advancing to 92.

div.head: Home Rails
div.p: A satisfactory feature is the firmness of home railway stocks, which are now receiving good support. The Scotch lines have been particularly favoured, and the tone of the market generally is now better than it has been for some time past. Yesterday much assistance was given by the publication of an excellent "batch of traffics, including £17,675 on the North Eastern, £15,000 on the North Western, £12,123 on the Midland, and £11,300 on the Great Western North Westerns and Great Westerns advanced it, but the feature was the bidding for South Westerns, which put the l'eferred up 2 to 493, and the Ordinary 1 to 1481.

div.head: Americans
div.p: Wall Street was again very excited at the beginning of the week, and quotations showed considerable fluctuating. The timely action of Mr. Cortelyou, the Treasury Secretary, in coming to the aid of the market has had a wonderful salutary effect, by relieving all fears of monetary stringency over the April settlements.
It is now believed that the worst is over, and that we shall soon see a general return of confidence.
The market here was at the beginning largely influenced by the conditions ruling in Wall $t, but a steady recovery set in on Tuesday, which has since made substantial progress
Yesterday the market was strong through out, and closed at about the best points touched. Louisvilles showed an advance of 6 to 120, Unions 5% to 1381, and Milwaukee 5 1/2 to 15xd

div.head: Egyptians
div.p: Egyptians fell in sympathy with other sections early in the week, but have since shown much improvement, and close steady. National Bank, after jumping to 24$ sellers, close 253 bid, and Agricultural, after being 87 sellers, are better at 8%. The Preference remain 98. ] and the Debentures 891-90). Daira Sanieh ] Ordinary close 154-16, and the Deferred about 1 88. Delta Preference Bearer are 104-114, with small buyers, at about 11. Delta Land and Investment are extremely nominal at 31-4, and 1 Egyptian Markets at i thit, and Salt and Soda at i to Egyptian Estates are 'steady at 2, ] but the Deferred show a fall of about 4 to 18-20 1

United Egyptian Lands, which were in demand at & premium, close easier at par to premium, and the Deferred at 8-9. Land and General Trust are quoted par to premium. Land Bank are down to 8+-, and Union Fonciere are flat 51- Anglo-Egyptian elise 138-1, and Bank of Roumania 94-10. There is absolutely nothing doing in Khedivial Mails, which are quoted 11-1, and the Preference 41+.

div.head: Mining
div.p: There was some forced liquidation in the mining section on Monday, which caused a heavy fall in some cases, but this has gradually diminished, and the market generally has now a firm appearance.. . | Yesterday Berlin gave assistance, and numerous buying orders for Kaffirs were received. Rand Mines closed at 6,23/32, a gain of 3/32, | and Modderfontein were 5/16 up at 6, H., There has been nothing doing in Egyptian mining sbares, which show little change. Nile Valleys are lower at 21s, but Egyptian Mines Expl, are still at 119.

div.head: SPINAL TORTURE
Dr. William's Pink Pills
div.p: A Helpless, Afflicted Woman. Lost Use of Her Limbs. Now Well and Walking. Her Strength Restored by
"I gladly give details of my wonderful cure by Dr. Williams' Pink Pills for Pale People, 'fer they lifted me from a bed of suffering,

after other treatments had left me in despair." * This was the statement of Mrs. McCann, living at 83, Jermyn-street, Bredford, who then des. cribed the spinal affliction that had for so long blighted her life.

"Five years ago," she added, "I began to feel a tingling sensation and numbness at the base of my spine. It was not very painful at first, but it caused me considerable uneasiness, When some time later I lost the use of my legs I became alarmed. The lower part of my body became icy cold, and I felt as if my back and sides were paralysed. In a few weeks I could not straighten my back; I felt a shrinkage at TUTOE WEDE the base of the spine.
which became soft and HER SYMPTOMS.
• flabby ; I was so helpless that I could only shuffle about the room, holding on to the furniture.

"My face and hands became emaciated and deathly pale, and a gnawing, throbbing pain attacked the back of my head and neck, while my nerves became so unstrung that even a noise upset me. My back and spine became inflamed and tender; even my clothing produced' an irritating and painful sensation. All this time my muscular power steadily diminished until I grew perfectly helpless. Eventually I was reduced to a mere skeleton, and to all appearances I did not have an ounce of blood in my body. I was taken to the hospital, where doctors said I was suffering from softening of the spine; they kept me in the hospital for months, and finally dis. charged me as incurable, I returned home and was carried to bed, where I lay, every movement of my body causing racking pains at the base of my spine. All attempts to strengthen my back were useless. All medicines failed to oure me or even give relief, and I was gradually wasting away. *;

I persevered with Dr. Williams' Pink Pills, gaining strength every day, and in four months was able to leave my bed and go downstairs, I was free from pain and could actually do a little housework." div.p: NOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN that an Extraordinary General Meeting of the above Company will be held at Winchester House, Old Broad Street, in the City of London, on Tuesday, the 16th day of April, 1907, at 2 o'clock in the afternoon, for the purpose of considering, and if thought fit, passing the following Resolutions, or Resolutions to a similar effect. Resolutions, numbered I., II. and III., will, if passed by the requisite majority, be submitted for confirmation to a Second General Meeting to be hereafter con vened so as to become Special Resolution

div.p: I. That the Special Resolution of the Company passed on the 19th day of July 1906, and confirmed on the 16th day of August, 1906, to the effect following :"That the Memorandum and Articles of

a) of the Memorandum of Association "the words in any district,' and by sub. "stituting for the words in which the "Railways belonging to, or that may at "any time hereafter helong to the Egyp"tian Delta Light Railways, Limited, or "any extension or branch thereof existing
or hereafter constrncted, or proposed to "be constructed, may serve or be intended "to serve, occurring in the same sub-section

ORDINARY RESOLUTIONS,

div.head: ORDINARY RESOLUTIONS
div.p: That the Capital of the Company be
and is hereby increased from £250,000
to £500,000. V. That the Directors be and are hereby

authorised to enter into an Agreement with the Egyptian Delta Light Rail. ways, Limited, whereby it shall be agreed that Clauses 3 and 4 of an Agree ment dated the 21st day of April, 1904, and made between the Company of the one part, and the Egyptian Delta Light Railways, Limited, of the other part, which said Clausės were cancelled by a letter dated the 27th July, 1900, shall be restored so as agnin to be of full force and effect. By order of the Board,
F. J. Horne,
Secretary. 211, GRESHAM House,
OLD BROAD STREET, E C.. Dated 27th March, 19 7.

Shareholders who hold Warrants to Bearer are reminded that if they wish to attend the Extraordinary General Meeting of the Company they must first deposit their Bearer Warrants, together with a statement in writing of their names and addresses, either at the Registered Office of the Company in Lon. don, two clear days before the Meeting, i.e., not later than the 13th April, or in Egypt with the National Bank of Egypt, the Bank of Egypt, the Anglo-Egyptian Bank, Limited, Credit Lyonnais,; or the Imperial Ottoman Bank; ten clear days before the date of the meeting, ie, not later than 5th April, the Share Wariants remaining so deposited until after the General Meeting shall have been held.
Each Depositor will receive a Certificate of Deposit in exchange for the Share Warrants deposited, 'which must be produced by the holders attending the Meeting 29904-6-5.

div.head: National Bank of Egypt
AVIS AUX ACTIONNAIRES
div.p: L'Assemblée Générale Ordinaire qui avait été convoquée pour le 23 Mars n'ayant pas réani le nombre d'actious voulo, Mossieurs les Aotionnaires de la National Bank of Egypt sont convoqués à pouvern en Assemblée Géné. rale Ordinaire pour le Jeudi 11 Avril 1907 à trois heures et demie de l'après-midi, an siège social, ao Caire,
Dans cette seconde réunion les délibérations seront valablement priser, quel que soit :e Dumbre des actions repré-entéer.
ORDRE DU JOUR : Rapport da Conseil d'administration, Rupport des Censeurs.
Approbation des comptes de l'exercice clos le 81 Décembre 1906.
Fixation da dividende.
Renouvellement partiel du Conseil d'Administration.
Election des Censeurs pour l'exeroide 1907. Fixation de l'indemnité des Censegre.
